div.p: Holy Reverend Father in Christ, I wrote yesterday, but today I ran into the courier, who said he would leave tomorrow. Meanwhile, it is written here that in Basel in France new tumults are being stirred up, Cond√© and the admiral are gathering forces anew, and a certain fortress has been burned. If these things are true, they will disturb everything for the French.

But because often many false rumors are spread, Mr. Consul and Carlinus, and I earnestly ask you to teach us the truth; for if things were as they are said, it would not be advisable for us to involve ourselves in such disturbances.

Please, do not keep us in the dark; we anxiously await to know what is happening. There is no need to wait for merchants; the host of the Stork sends reliable men with letters every third day, through whom you can also take care of your matters.
Farewell, Reverend Father in Christ, and forgive me for being so often a bother to you. Chur, the day before the calends of December in the year 1564.
Your most observant Johannes Fabricius. That news greatly frightened us; for if it were true, the Spaniard could do much on this occasion. But we hope for better things.
